hints_html: Again, use implicit differentiation. You will need to use the quotient rule as well.
hints_latex:
Again, use implicit differentiation. You will need to use the quotient
rule as well.
hints_raw: Again, use implicit differentiation.  You will need to use the quotient rule as well.
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
To find \(y''\) we simply need to differentiate the expression \(y' = -x^3/y^3\) from part (a). Using implicit differentiation and the quotient rule, we have:

\[\begin{aligned} y'' &= \frac{-3x^2(y^3) - (-x^3)3y^2y'}{(y^3)^2} \\ &= \frac{3x^2y^2(-y + xy')}{y^6} \\ &= \frac{3x^2(-y + x y')}{y^4} \end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
To find <math>y''</math> we simply need to differentiate the expression <math>y' = -x^3/y^3</math> from part (a).  Using implicit differentiation and the quotient rule, we have: 

<math>\begin{align}
y'' &= \frac{-3x^2(y^3) - (-x^3)3y^2y'}{(y^3)^2} \\
&= \frac{3x^2y^2(-y + xy')}{y^6} \\
&= \frac{3x^2(-y + x y')}{y^4} \\
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
Given a curve, its curvature K is a measure of how much it deviates from a straight line. It can be computed using the following formula:

\[\begin{aligned} K = \frac{y''}{\left(1+(y')^2\right)^{3/2}}\end{aligned}\]

In this question you will calculate the curvature of the curve x4 + y4 = 2 at a certain point.

Use your answer from part (a) to calculate \(\displaystyle y''\).
statement_raw:
''Given a curve, its '''curvature''' K is a measure of how much it deviates from a straight line. It can be computed using the following formula:''

:<math>
K = \frac{y''}{\left(1+(y')^2\right)^{3/2}}
</math>

''In this question you will calculate the curvature of the curve x<sup>4</sup> + y<sup>4</sup> = 2 at a certain point.''

Use your answer from part [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/April_2011/Question_4_(a)|(a)]] to calculate <math>\displaystyle y''</math>.
